title: Fuel Tank - Installation

body.body: Warning - General - Stabilise Motorcycle Including locking devices
Warning - General - Stabilise Motorcycle - including DO NOT support on non integral parts
Make sure the motorcycle is stabilised and adequately supported.
Do not support the motorcycle on any ancillary component, the exhaust system or any other non structural parts of the motorcycle frame.
A correctly supported motorcycle will help prevent it from falling.
An unstable motorcycle may fall resulting in motorcycle damage, serious injury or death.
Note to be used in service manual with stabilise warning
Renew locking devices where specified, refer to
Before tightening a fixing using a crow foot spanner adapter, refer to
Use of Crow Foot Spanner Adapters with Torque Wrenches
Observe all torque wrench tightening procedures, refer to
Measure the hose at the fuel tank end so that there is 7mm of clearance (
) between the end of the spring and the end of the EVAP hose.
Position the wire hose clip to hold the spring in the correct position.
With the aid of an assistant, align the fuel tank above its mountings.
Connect the electrical connector for the fuel pump and level sensor.
Connect the fuel feed hose by gently pushing the connector inwards until the hose engages onto the fuel pump spigot with a click.
Pull the hose connector gently to make sure it is correctly secured.
Make sure the wire hose clips are placed over the drain hose and EVAP hose before fitting them to the fuel tank.
Fit the EVAP hose to the corresponding fuel tank boss and secure with the wire hose clip.
Fit the drain hose to the corresponding fuel tank boss and secure with the wire hose clip.
Check the end of the spring is 7 mm from the end of the EVAP hose (
) and secure with the wire hose clip.
Make sure that the fuel hose is correctly routed. If the fuel hose is incorrectly routed, it can become kinked and reduce the fuel flow. This can cause the engine to misfire or stop.
An engine that misfires or stops may lead to a dangerous riding condition, leading to loss of motorcycle control which could result in serious injury or death.
Route the fuel hose as noted during removal.
Lower the fuel tank onto its mountings. Make sure that the fuel hose does not become kinked.
Make sure that the spacer is still positioned in between the rubber grommets at the rear mounting.
Insert the bolt through the spacer, fit the nut but do not fully tighten at this stage.
Hold the bolt in position and tighten the nut to
Follow the warning advice given in the General Information section on the safe handling of fuel and fuel containers.
A fire that causes personal injury and damage to property could result from spilled fuel or fuel not handled or stored correctly.
Use workshop equipment approved for fuel handling to refill the fuel tank with the fuel previously removed.
Reconnect the battery, positive (red) lead first. Tighten the battery terminals to
Check carefully for fuel leaks. Rectify as necessary.

Make sure that the fuel hose is correctly routed. If the fuel hose is incorrectly routed, it can become kinked and reduce the fuel flow. This can cause the engine to misfire or stop.
An engine that misfires or stops may lead to a dangerous riding condition, leading to loss of motorcycle control which could result in serious injury or death.

Lower the fuel tank onto its mountings. Make sure that the fuel hose does not become kinked.
Make sure that the spacer is still positioned in between the rubber grommets at the rear mounting.
Insert the bolt through the spacer, fit the nut but do not fully tighten at this stage.

A fire that causes personal injury and damage to property could result from spilled fuel or fuel not handled or stored correctly.

Battery - Installation
Seat - Installation
